Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
National Geographic Television will develop a television series (tentatively titled "Aqua Kids") and transmedia program to introduce preschoolers and kindergarteners to the wonders and value of water. The goal is to empower young children's innate sense of inquiry and increase early environmental literacy by motivating young learners to make discoveries with water, inside and outside their homes. The grant would allow the National Geographic project team to: 1) research cutting-edge practices for teaching early learners environmental literacy and water principles; 2) convene content and creative advisors; 3) test one storybook and animatic (animated storyboard) with the target audience and their parents; 4) strategize best ways to create a transmedia project that capitalizes on emerging digital platforms, reaches audiences most in need, and takes advantage of National Geographic resources, including National Geographic's ongoing global water conservation outreach missions. Insight Research Group will conduct formative evaluation using the animatic and interviews with parents to help identify barriers to extend the television experience with their children to outdoor activities and beyond.

The project partners include Project WET, a youth water education project, NOAA's Office of Marine Sanctuaries, USDA Forest Service, the National Park Service as well as a number of museums and Think It Ink It Publishing.

This Pathways Project will allow the project team to complete the groundwork necessary to create an innovative new multiplatform educational media resource. The Water Show will inspire outdoor science play, build inquiry and social skills and create a vital foundation for caring and respecting the most valuable natural resource, water. Fostering early appreciation for how Earth's "green parts" are wholly dependent on its "blue parts" is foundational for subsequent scientific learning and instrumental in building lasting respect for living systems and natural resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was initially conceived of as a science-based TV series for children ages 3-6.  A series bible was developed, and an initial season of episodes was planned. Although intended to air on PBS, the network ultimately declined, and the series was reworked as a digital educational game app about the ocean, its care, and the life it supports.


The Apple iPad was selected as the most compelling technology platform to create this digital experience, as a tool that is used for informal learning through gameplay, featuring an engaging character to act as a guide through the iPad app.


The final result of this pivot was the development of Marine Missions, a water education app aimed at a preschool and early learner audience. The app educates through a gameplay interface. Players guide Jacques the hermit crab through a series of special water current challenges and help him clean up the ocean, then they can go on to create their own unique aquatic animals while learning about the unique adaptations of marine animal life.


An activity packet was developed to complement the app’s content. This packet was delivered to the Monterey Bay Aquarium, and made available to families on mybigcampus.com. The Water Learning Framework was also developed, and will be made available to educators on informalscience.org.


The summative testing showed that the app was appealing to children, and by playing the game children learned that it is important to keep the ocean clean. The most popular segment of the app was the Creature Builder, in which children can create their own animal. This section of the game does not have a defined start or finish, and children were drawn to the opportunity to express their creativity through free play.


Based on the reactions of the children evaluated in the summative testing, we have concluded that the iPad is a valid tool for informal educational purposes, but it is best to keep to a simple concept, focusing on one core mechanic. The summative evaluations indicate which elements of the app best engaged our audience’s attention (e.g. building their own creature, playing the whirlpool, cleaning up the ocean,) and the validity of our main character (Jacques the hermit crab) as a guide into the ocean world.
